steps.description: Did you never ask NAV about anything? Are you not expecting a package? Then the message is probably fake. Think about whether it makes sense that you received this message.
steps.warning: Scammers send millions of messages - sometimes they accidentally hit the right timing.

steps.title: Don't download attachments
steps.description: Never open attachments from unknown senders. They may contain viruses or malware. Also be careful with attachments from known senders if the message seems strange.
steps.warning: Particularly dangerous are .exe, .zip and .docm files.

steps.title: Verify via official channels
steps.description: Unsure if a message is real? Contact the sender directly via official channels. Find the phone number on their official website, not in the email you received.
steps.tip: Call NAV at 55 55 33 33 or the bank at the number on the back of your card.

warningSigns: Generic greeting like "Dear customer" instead of your name
Sender address that doesn't match the company
Links that go to different domains than expected
Demands to act quickly or lose something
Request for personal information, passwords or codes
Poor formatting, strange fonts or weird layout
phishing.ifClickedTitle: What do you do if you've clicked?
phishing.ifClicked1: Don't enter any information - close the page immediately
phishing.ifClicked2: Scan the computer with antivirus software
phishing.ifClicked3: Change your passwords if you have provided any
phishing.ifClicked4: Contact your bank if it concerns bank details
phishing.ifClicked5: Report the fraud to the police and Nettvett.no

svindel.title: Avoid fraud
svindel.description: Learn to recognize and avoid fraud attempts
svindel.longDescription: Learn to recognize and avoid fraud attempts via phone, SMS and email. Especially important for elderly.
svindel.checklistIntro: Did you receive a phone call, SMS or email you're unsure about? Answer the questions below:

checklistItems.question: Did they contact YOU first?
checklistItems.warning: Real banks and authorities rarely contact you unsolicited.

checklistItems.question: Are they asking for password, BankID or national ID number?
checklistItems.warning: NEVER give this out - real senders never ask for it!

checklistItems.question: Is it very urgent?
checklistItems.warning: Scammers always create urgency. Real matters can wait until tomorrow.

checklistItems.question: Do you have to pay to receive something?
checklistItems.warning: Real prizes and inheritance never require you to pay first.

checklistItems.question: Does it seem too good to be true?
checklistItems.warning: Then it's almost always too good to be true.

checklistItems.question: Should you keep it secret?
checklistItems.warning: Scammers don't want you talking to others who might expose them.

checklistItems.question: Do they want cash or gift cards?
checklistItems.warning: Real companies never take payment in gift cards.

svindel.checklistResultSafe: Looks safe, but always be vigilant!
svindel.checklistResultCaution: Be careful! {count} warning signs. Talk to someone you trust before doing anything.
svindel.checklistResultDanger: STOP! {count} warning signs. This is probably fraud. Don't do anything!
svindel.checklistPrintMessage: Use the checklist above to evaluate if you've been contacted by scammers.
svindel.elderScamIntro: Scammers often target elderly because they may be more trusting and have savings. Here are the most common types:

elderScamTypes.title: Grandchild scam
elderScamTypes.description: Someone calls pretending to be your grandchild. They say they're in trouble and need money fast - often for lawyer, bail or hospital bill.
elderScamTypes.howItWorks: The scammer calls and says "Hi grandma/grandpa, it's me!" and hopes you say your grandchild's name. Then they pretend to be that person.
redFlags: They ask you NOT to tell their parents
They need the money VERY fast
They want cash or gift cards
The voice sounds "different" - they say they have a cold
elderScamTypes.whatToDo: Hang up and call your grandchild on the number you have saved. Ask about something only the two of you know.

elderScamTypes.title: Microsoft/Apple scam
elderScamTypes.description: Someone calls saying they're from Microsoft, Apple or "tech support". They claim your computer has a virus and they need to help you remove it.
elderScamTypes.howItWorks: They get you to install a program that gives them control over your computer. Then they "find" problems and demand payment.
redFlags: Microsoft and Apple NEVER call unsolicited
They ask for remote access to your computer
They want payment in gift cards or cryptocurrency
They threaten that your computer will stop working
elderScamTypes.whatToDo: Hang up immediately. Real tech support never calls you first.

elderScamTypes.title: Romance scam
elderScamTypes.description: Someone you met online (often on Facebook or dating sites) says they're in love with you. Eventually they ask for money.
elderScamTypes.howItWorks: They build a relationship over weeks or months. Then a "crisis" occurs - they need money for plane ticket, medical treatment or customs.
redFlags: They can never meet face to face
They declare love very quickly
They always have excuses for not video calling
They ask for money - for any reason
elderScamTypes.whatToDo: Never send money to someone you only know from the internet. Talk to family or friends about the relationship.

elderScamTypes.title: Lottery scam
elderScamTypes.description: You're told you've won a lottery you never entered. But you have to pay "fee" or "tax" to receive the prize.
elderScamTypes.howItWorks: They send email or call with "good news". To get the million prize you just have to pay a small amount first.
redFlags: You haven't bought a ticket or entered the competition
You have to pay to receive the prize
They ask for bank information to "transfer the prize"
The prize is in foreign currency
elderScamTypes.whatToDo: Ignore it. You can't win lotteries you haven't entered.

elderScamTypes.title: Investment scam
elderScamTypes.description: Someone promises you fantastic returns on investments in stocks, cryptocurrency or other "opportunities".
elderScamTypes.howItWorks: They contact you with a "unique opportunity". Often they show fake websites that look like your investments are growing.
redFlags: The returns are too good to be true (20-50% or more)
They pressure you to invest quickly
You've never heard of the company before
They call from abroad or have a foreign accent
elderScamTypes.whatToDo: Talk to your bank before investing. Check the Financial Supervisory Authority's list of warnings.

elderScamTypes.title: Contractor scam
elderScamTypes.description: Someone knocks on your door offering to fix the roof, driveway or something else "they happened to see needed repair".
elderScamTypes.howItWorks: They do a poor or unnecessary job and demand high payment in cash. Sometimes they disappear with the advance payment.
redFlags: They "happened" to be in the neighborhood
They want payment in advance or cash
They have no written quote or contract
They pressure you to decide immediately
elderScamTypes.whatToDo: Say no to unsolicited offers. Use contractors you know or who are recommended by someone you trust.

otherScamTypes.title: Phone scam
otherScamTypes.description: Someone calls pretending to be from the bank, police or Microsoft. They want access to your account.

otherScamTypes.title: SMS scam
otherScamTypes.description: "Your package is waiting" or "You've won!" - messages with links leading to fake websites.

otherScamTypes.title: Email scam (phishing)
otherScamTypes.description: Emails that look like they come from the bank or others you trust, but want to trick you.

svindel.stepsTitle: How to protect yourself from fraud

steps.title: Stop and think
steps.description: Scammers try to stress you into acting fast. Take your time. Real banks and authorities always give you time to think.
steps.tip: If someone says "this is urgent!" or "you must act NOW!", it's almost always fraud.

steps.title: Check who's contacting you
steps.description: Look carefully at who's calling or sending the message. Scammers can fake phone numbers and email addresses, but there are often small errors.
steps.warning: Your bank will NEVER call and ask for password, BankID code or national ID number!

steps.title: Look for spelling errors
steps.description: Real messages from banks and authorities are always written with correct grammar. Scam messages often have spelling errors, strange phrasing or poor grammar.
steps.tip: Read the message out loud. Does it sound strange? Then it's probably fraud.

steps.title: Don't click links in messages
steps.description: Scammers often send links that look real but lead to fake websites. Instead, go directly to the bank's website by typing the address yourself.
steps.warning: Never log in via links in email or SMS. Always type the address yourself in the browser.

steps.title: Never share personal information
steps.description: Passwords, BankID codes, national ID numbers and card information should NEVER be shared with anyone who contacts you. Real companies never ask for this.

steps.title: Call back on official number
steps.description: If someone calls saying they're from the bank, hang up and call the bank's official number. Find the number on the bank's website or on the back of your bank card.
steps.tip: Don't call back on the number that called you - it can also be faked.

steps.title: Talk to someone you trust
steps.description: Are you unsure? Talk to family, friends or your bank before doing anything. It's better to ask once too many than to be tricked.

svindel.neverAskTitle: Remember: Real senders will NEVER ask you for...
neverAskList: To install programs on your computer
To transfer money to a "safe account"

examples.message: Your package is waiting for delivery. Pay 29 kr shipping here: [link]
examples.warning: Post offices never send SMS about payment via links!

examples.message: Hello, this is from the bank's security department. We've detected suspicious activity and need to verify your BankID.
examples.warning: The bank NEVER calls about BankID!

examples.message: Dear customer, your account will be closed if you don't update your information within 24 hours.
examples.warning: Real banks never threaten account closure via email!

examples.message: Hi grandma, it's me! I've been in an accident and need 50,000 kr for a lawyer. Can you help? But don't tell mom!
examples.warning: Real grandchildren don't ask you to keep things secret from parents!

contacts.title: Emergency number - Police
contacts.description: For immediate danger or ongoing crime

contacts.title: Police service number
contacts.description: To report fraud or get advice

contacts.title: ID theft helpline
contacts.description: If someone has misused your identity

contacts.title: Find it on the back of your card
contacts.description: Block card and account in case of fraud

svindel.contactsTip: Write down these numbers and keep the note by your phone!

passord.title: Creating good passwords
passord.description: How to create strong passwords that protect you
passord.longDescription: Good passwords are your first line of defense against hackers. Here you learn to create passwords that are both secure and easy to remember.
passord.whyImportantText1: A weak password can be cracked in seconds. Hackers use programs that try millions of combinations automatically. If your password is "123456" or "password", you're not protected at all.
passord.whyImportantText2: With a strong password, it takes years to crack your account, and hackers move on to easier targets.
passord.badPasswordsWarning: If you use any of these, change them IMMEDIATELY!

steps.title: Use at least 12 characters
steps.description: The longer the password, the more secure. A 12-character password is much harder to crack than an 8-character one. Aim for at least 12 characters, preferably more.
steps.tip: A sentence is easier to remember than random characters: "MyCatIsNamedLars2024!" is 20 characters and easy to remember.

steps.title: Mix upper and lower case letters, numbers and symbols
steps.description: A good password contains both upper and lower case letters, at least one number, and at least one special character (!@#$%&). This makes it much harder to guess.
steps.tip: Replace letters with numbers or symbols: "Summer" becomes "S0mm3r!" (but don't use only common substitutions).

steps.title: Use a passphrase
steps.description: Instead of one word, use a whole sentence. "CoffeeIsBestAt7Morning!" is 21 characters, contains everything needed, and is easy to remember.
steps.tip: Choose a sentence that makes sense to you, but that others can't guess.

steps.title: Never reuse passwords
steps.description: Use a unique password for each service. If one site gets hacked and you use the same password everywhere, hackers get access to everything.
steps.warning: Online banking, email and public services MUST have different passwords!

steps.title: Use a password manager
steps.description: A password manager stores all your passwords securely, so you only need to remember one master password. Programs like Bitwarden, 1Password or LastPass make this easy.
steps.tip: Password managers can also create random, strong passwords for you.

steps.title: Enable two-factor authentication
steps.description: Two-factor (2FA) means you need both a password AND a code from your phone to log in. Even if someone steals your password, they can't get in without your phone.
steps.tip: Turn on 2FA on all services that offer it, especially online banking and email.

steps.title: Change password if it may be compromised
steps.description: If a service you use has been hacked, or you suspect someone has seen your password, change it immediately. Check haveibeenpwned.com to see if your email has been in a data breach.

tips: Never write down passwords on notes by the computer
Never share passwords with others, not even family
Always log out of shared computers
Be careful about saving passwords in the browser on others' devices
Update your passwords at least once a year
passord.toolPasswordManagerDesc: Bitwarden (free), 1Password or LastPass store your passwords securely.
passord.toolHaveIBeenPwnedDesc: Check if your email has been in a data breach at haveibeenpwned.com
passord.toolPasswordGeneratorDesc: Most password managers have a built-in generator for strong passwords.

nettbank.title: Getting started with online banking
nettbank.description: Learn to use your online bank safely and easily
nettbank.longDescription: Online banking lets you pay bills and check your account from home. Here you learn the basics.
nettbank.whatIsText1: Online banking is the bank's service on the internet. There you can see how much money you have, pay bills, transfer money between accounts, and much more - without visiting the bank physically.
nettbank.whatIsText2: All Norwegian banks offer online banking, and it's safe to use as long as you follow simple security rules.
beforeYouStartItems: You need BankID (on mobile or code device)
You must have a bank account
You need internet on computer, tablet or phone
nettbank.stepsTitle: How to get started with online banking

steps.title: Find the bank's website
steps.description: Open the browser and type in the bank's address. For example dnb.no, nordea.no, sparebank1.no, or sbanken.no. Don't click on links in email - always type the address yourself.
steps.tip: Save the bank's website as a favorite/bookmark so you can easily find it again.

steps.title: Click on "Log in" or "Online banking"
steps.description: On the bank's front page you'll find a button to log in. It's often called "Logg inn", "Nettbank" or "Min side". Click on this.
steps.tip: The button is usually in the top right corner of the page.

steps.title: Choose login method
steps.description: You can log in with BankID on mobile or BankID with code device. Choose the method you have access to.
steps.warning: If you don't have BankID, you must contact your bank to get it.

steps.title: Log in with BankID on mobile
steps.description: Enter your national ID number and phone number. You receive a message on your phone. Open the BankID app and approve with fingerprint, face or code.
steps.tip: Make sure the BankID app is updated to the latest version.

steps.title: Get familiar with the overview
steps.description: After logging in you see an overview of your accounts. Here you see the balance (how much money you have) on each account. Click on an account to see transactions (deposits and withdrawals).
steps.tip: Most online banks also show pending payments and upcoming bills.

steps.title: Explore the menu
steps.description: In the menu you find services like "Pay", "Transfer", "Cards", "Loans" and "Settings". Take time to look through what's available.
steps.tip: Many banks have a "Help" or "Customer service" button if you get stuck.

steps.title: Remember to log out
steps.description: When you're done, click "Log out" in the top right corner. This is especially important if you're using a shared computer.
steps.warning: Always close the browser window after you've logged out.

securityTips: Never log in via links in email or SMS
Only use online banking on your own device, not on public computers
Always log out when you're done
Check that the address starts with https:// and has a padlock icon
Never share BankID codes with anyone
nettbank.helpText: All banks have customer service that can help you. Call the bank's phone number (on the back of your bank card) or visit a branch.

betaling.title: Pay bills
betaling.description: How to pay bills in online banking
betaling.longDescription: Paying bills in online banking is fast and easy. Here we show you step-by-step how to do it.
whatYouNeed: The bill you will pay (paper or digital)
betaling.termKIDDesc: A long number sequence that identifies your payment. IMPORTANT to type correctly!
betaling.termFristDesc: Last day the bill must be paid

steps.title: Log in to online banking
steps.description: Go to the bank's website and log in with BankID as usual.

steps.title: Find "Pay" or "New payment"
steps.description: In the menu you'll find "Pay", "Payment" or "New payment". Click on this to start a new payment.
steps.tip: Some banks have a large "Pay" button on the front page.

steps.title: Select account to pay from
steps.description: Select which account the money should be taken from. Check that you have enough money in the account.
steps.warning: If you don't have enough money, the payment won't go through.

steps.title: Enter account number
steps.description: Enter the recipient's account number (11 digits). You can find this on the bill, often labeled "To account" or "Account number".
steps.tip: Some bills have a barcode - then you can use the bank's app to scan it automatically.

steps.title: Enter KID number
steps.description: Enter the KID number exactly as it appears on the bill. This is important so the recipient knows what the payment is for.
steps.warning: Wrong KID can cause the payment not to be registered correctly!

steps.title: Enter the amount
steps.description: Enter the amount you will pay. Check that it matches the bill.
steps.tip: Use comma for cents (e.g. 1234,50). Some banks use period.

steps.title: Select payment date
steps.description: Select when the payment should be made. You can pay immediately or set a future date. Remember that the due date is the deadline.
steps.tip: Pay a few days before the due date to make sure it arrives on time.

steps.title: Review and approve
steps.description: Review all the information: account number, KID, amount and date. When everything is correct, click "Pay" or "Approve".
steps.warning: Double-check KID and amount before approving!

steps.title: Confirmation
steps.description: You receive confirmation that the payment is registered. The payment will be deducted from your account on the selected date.
steps.tip: Save the receipt or take a screenshot for your own documentation.

betaling.avtaleGiroText: For bills that come regularly (electricity, insurance, etc.) you can set up AvtaleGiro. Then the bill is paid automatically each time. You can find this under "AvtaleGiro" or "Fixed payments" in online banking.
betaling.efakturaText: eFaktura means the bill comes directly into your online bank digitally. You don't need to type KID and account number - just approve the amount. Turn on eFaktura under "Settings" in online banking.

vipps.title: Using Vipps
vipps.description: Learn to send money and pay with Vipps
vipps.longDescription: Vipps makes it easy to send money to friends, pay in stores and split bills. Here you learn everything you need.
vipps.whatIsText1: Vipps is a Norwegian payment app that lets you send money to others, pay in stores, and much more - all from your phone.
vipps.whatIsText2: Over 4 million Norwegians use Vipps. It's safe because it's connected to BankID and your bank account.
vipps.stepsTitle: How to get started with Vipps

steps.title: Download the Vipps app
steps.description: Open App Store (iPhone) or Google Play (Android). Search for "Vipps" and press "Install" or "Get".
steps.tip: Make sure you download the real Vipps app with the orange logo.

steps.title: Open the app and start registration
steps.description: Open Vipps and press "Get started" or "Register". You'll be asked to enter your mobile number.
steps.tip: Use the same number that is registered in BankID.

steps.title: Confirm with BankID
steps.description: You must confirm your identity with BankID. Follow the instructions - you'll be sent to the BankID app to approve.
steps.warning: If BankID doesn't work, check that the app is updated.

steps.title: Connect bank account
steps.description: Vipps automatically retrieves your bank accounts. Select which account you want to use as default for Vipps payments.
steps.tip: You can change account later under "Settings" in the app.

steps.title: Add payment card (optional)
steps.description: You can also add a payment card to use Vipps in stores. Press "Card" and "Add card". Fill in the card information.
steps.tip: The card must support contactless payment.

steps.title: Send money to someone
steps.description: To send money: Press the "Search" or "+" button, enter name or number, enter the amount, and press "Send". The recipient also needs Vipps.
steps.tip: You can add a message to the payment, e.g. "Thanks for dinner!"

steps.title: Pay in store
steps.description: In stores that accept Vipps: Open the app, press "Pay", and hold the phone against the payment terminal. Approve with fingerprint or code.
steps.tip: Look for the Vipps logo at the checkout to know if the store accepts Vipps.

steps.title: Split bills
steps.description: Have you paid for something? Press "Bills" in the app, enter the total amount and select who should split. Vipps automatically sends a request to everyone.
steps.tip: Perfect for splitting bills after restaurant or shared purchases.

vipps.featuresTitle: More you can do with Vipps
vipps.featureInvoiceDesc: Receive and pay invoices directly in the app
vipps.featureRecurringDesc: Set up recurring payments to e.g. gym
vipps.featureOnlineDesc: Pay easily in online stores that offer Vipps
vipps.securityText: Vipps is safe because all payments are approved with fingerprint, face or PIN code. No one can send money from your account without your approval.

gjeld.title: Get help with debt
gjeld.description: Here you find help if you struggle to pay bills
gjeld.longDescription: Anyone can end up in a difficult financial situation. Here you find information about where to get help.
gjeld.importantText: If you struggle to pay bills, it's important to act quickly. The sooner you take action, the easier it is to find a solution. You're not alone - many have been in the same situation and received help.
signs: You only pay the minimum amount on credit cards
You use credit cards for daily expenses like food
You take out new loans to pay old ones
You avoid opening mail and bills

steps.title: Get an overview of your finances
steps.description: Write down all income (salary, benefits, etc.) and all expenses (rent, food, loans, etc.). This gives you an overview of the situation.
steps.tip: Use the online bank's transaction overview to see what you actually spend money on.

steps.title: Prioritize the bills
steps.description: Some bills are more important than others. Pay first: rent/mortgage, electricity, food, and any child support. Consumer loans and credit cards can wait.
steps.warning: If you don't pay rent, you risk losing your home.

steps.title: Contact your creditors
steps.description: Call those you owe money and explain the situation. Most would rather make a payment plan than send the case to collections. Ask for payment deferral or installment arrangement.
steps.tip: Many creditors have their own arrangements for those who struggle. Ask about lower interest or longer repayment time.

steps.title: Seek professional help
steps.description: Debt advisors can help you negotiate with creditors and make a plan. This is free at the municipality and NAV.
steps.tip: You don't need to have decided anything before contacting - they help you see the possibilities.

steps.title: Consider refinancing
steps.description: If you have many small loans, it may pay off to consolidate them into one loan with lower interest. Talk to your bank about the options.
steps.warning: Be careful with "consolidation loans" with high interest from unknown companies.

steps.title: Apply for financial social assistance if necessary
steps.description: If you don't have money for food and necessary expenses, you can apply for social assistance from NAV. This is temporary help while you get your finances in order.
steps.tip: Social assistance is a right for those who need it - don't be afraid to apply.

gjeld.helpTitle: Where can you get free help?
gjeld.helpNAVDesc: Call NAV at 55 55 33 33 and ask to speak with a debt counselor, or visit your local NAV office.
gjeld.helpKommuneDesc: Most municipalities have free debt counseling. Call the municipality service office for contact information.
gjeld.helpOkonomiradDesc: Consumer Council website with budget tools and financial advice.
gjeld.helpGjeldsofferDesc: Voluntary organization providing free advice and support to people with debt problems.
avoidItems: Taking out new loans to pay old ones (debt spiral)
Saying yes to "quick loans" with high interest
Waiting too long to seek help

epost.title: Set up email
epost.description: Learn to create and use email
epost.longDescription: Email is fundamental for digital communication. Here you learn to create an email account and use it.
epost.whatIsText1: Email (electronic mail) is digital mail you send and receive via the internet. It's free, fast, and you can send to anyone in the world.
epost.whatIsText2: To use email you need an email address. This works as your digital address, e.g. name@gmail.com.
epost.providerGmailDesc: Most popular, free, works on all devices
epost.providerYahooDesc: Free, has existed for a long time
epost.stepsTitle: How to create a Gmail account

steps.title: Go to Gmail
steps.description: Open the browser and go to gmail.com. Click on "Create account".

steps.title: Fill in personal information
steps.description: Enter first name and last name. This is shown when you send email.
steps.tip: Use your real name so people recognize you.

steps.title: Choose email address
steps.description: Choose your email address. It must be unique. Try firstname.lastname@gmail.com or add numbers if the address is taken.
steps.warning: The address cannot be changed later, so choose carefully!

steps.title: Create a strong password
steps.description: Create a password with at least 8 characters, preferably 12. Use both upper and lower case letters, numbers and symbols. Confirm the password by typing it again.
steps.tip: See our password guide for tips on creating a secure password.

steps.title: Add phone number (recommended)
steps.description: Add your mobile number to be able to recover the account if you forget the password. You can also use it for extra security.
steps.tip: This is optional, but strongly recommended.

steps.title: Accept the terms
steps.description: Read through and accept Google's terms and privacy policy by clicking "Accept" or "I agree".

steps.title: Your email is ready!
steps.description: Congratulations! You now have an email address. You arrive at your inbox where new emails will appear.
steps.tip: Save the email address and password in a safe place.

sendSteps: Enter recipient's email address in the "To" field
replySteps: Open the email you want to reply to
attachmentSteps: Start a new email or reply
Select the file from your computer
Wait for the file to upload
epost.spamText: Spam is unwanted email, often advertising or fraud attempts. Gmail and other services automatically filter most to a "Spam" folder. Never check links in suspicious emails.

digipost.title: Using Digipost
digipost.description: Receive digital mail from public and private senders
digipost.longDescription: Digipost is your digital mailbox where you receive mail from the public sector and businesses. Safe, easy and environmentally friendly.
digipost.whatIsText1: Digipost is a secure digital mailbox where you receive letters from public agencies (like the Tax Office and NAV) and private companies (like your bank and insurance company).
digipost.whatIsText2: Instead of paper mail, you get everything digitally, and it's stored safely for years.
benefits: All mail collected in one place
Get notification when new mail arrives

steps.title: Go to digipost.no
steps.description: Open the browser and go to digipost.no. Click on "Register" or "Create account".

steps.title: Log in with BankID
steps.description: You register with BankID. Choose BankID on mobile or code device and follow the instructions.
steps.warning: You must have BankID to use Digipost.

steps.title: Confirm information
steps.description: Digipost automatically retrieves name and address from the Population Register. Check that the information is correct.
steps.tip: Add email address and mobile number to get notification of new mail.

steps.title: Choose who should send you mail
steps.description: You can choose which senders should send you digital mail. Public agencies are automatically enabled. You can also add banks, insurance companies, etc.
steps.tip: You can change this at any time under "Settings".

steps.title: Explore the mailbox
steps.description: In the mailbox you see all received mail. You can create folders to organize, and search for old letters.
steps.tip: Mail from the public sector is often under "Public sector" or in separate folders.

steps.title: Download the app (optional)
steps.description: You can also use Digipost on your phone. Download the app from App Store or Google Play.
steps.tip: With the app you get push notifications when new mail arrives.

tips: Check Digipost regularly - important mail may arrive there
Use the search function to find old letters
Create folders to stay organized
Download important documents as backup

altinn.title: Using Altinn
altinn.description: Submit forms and communicate with the public sector
altinn.longDescription: Altinn is the portal where you submit forms to the public sector and find information about your rights and obligations.
altinn.whatIsText1: Altinn is the public sector's common portal for digital communication. Here you can submit forms, check status of cases, and find information from over 70 public agencies.
altinn.whatIsText2: You use Altinn for things like tax return, driver's license, building permit and much more.
altinn.commonUsesTitle: This is what you use Altinn for

steps.title: Go to altinn.no
steps.description: Open the browser and go to altinn.no.

steps.title: Log in
steps.description: Click "Log in" in the top right corner. Choose BankID, MinID or other login method. Follow the instructions to log in.
steps.tip: BankID gives access to most services.

steps.title: Explore "My profile"
steps.description: After logging in you see "My profile" or "Your dashboard". Here you see messages, forms and status of submitted cases.
steps.tip: Check "Inbox" for messages from the public sector.

steps.title: Find a form
steps.description: To find a form, use the search field or click on "Forms and services". Type what you're looking for, e.g. "tax return" or "moving notification".
steps.tip: Popular forms are often on the front page.

steps.title: Fill out the form
steps.description: Open the form and fill in all fields. Many forms have pre-filled information. Check that everything is correct.
steps.warning: Save along the way if the form is long - you can continue later.

steps.title: Submit
steps.description: When the form is completed, click "Submit" or "Deliver". You may need to sign with BankID.
steps.tip: You get a receipt as confirmation. Keep this.

steps.title: Monitor status
steps.description: In "My cases" or "Inbox" you can see status of what you have submitted. You also get a message when the case is processed.

tips: Check the inbox regularly for important messages
Use the archive to find previously submitted forms
You can authorize others to act on your behalf
Many municipal services require Altinn login

minside.title: MinSide and public services
minside.description: An overview of the most important public online services
minside.longDescription: There are several "My page" services at various public agencies. Here you get an overview of the most important ones.
minside.introText: "My page" or "My profile" is what you see when you log in to public agencies. There you find your personal information, applications, decisions and messages.
minside.serviceNAVDesc: Applications, decisions, employment cards, sick pay
minside.serviceSkattDesc: Tax return, tax settlement, tax card
minside.serviceAltinnDesc: Forms, company, messages from public sector
minside.serviceDigipostDesc: Digital mailbox for public and private mail
minside.stepsTitle: How to log in to public services

steps.title: Go to the service website
steps.description: Type the address directly in the browser, e.g. nav.no, skatteetaten.no or helsenorge.no.
steps.warning: Never click on links in email to log in - always go directly to the website.

steps.title: Find "Log in"
steps.description: Look for "Log in", "My page" or similar. The button is usually in the top right corner of the page.

steps.title: Choose login method
steps.description: You can choose between different login methods. The most common are BankID on mobile, BankID with code device, or MinID.
steps.tip: BankID gives access to most services. MinID works on some.

steps.title: Confirm your identity
steps.description: Follow the instructions for chosen login method. With BankID on mobile you receive a message you must approve.
steps.warning: Always read what you approve before confirming!

steps.title: You're in!
steps.description: After logging in you're on "My page" where you find your personal information and services.
steps.tip: Remember to log out when you're done.

tips: Use the same login method everywhere for simplicity
Check the inbox regularly - important messages arrive there
Update your contact information if it changes
Always log out when using a shared computer

bostotte.title: Apply for housing allowance
bostotte.description: Get financial support to pay rent or housing costs
bostotte.longDescription: Housing allowance is a government support scheme for those with low income and high housing costs. Both tenants and homeowners can apply.
bostotte.whatIsText1: Housing allowance is money from Husbanken to help you pay for your home. It's means-tested, meaning your income and housing costs determine if you get support.
bostotte.whatIsText2: You can get housing allowance whether you rent or own your home. The support is paid monthly directly to your account.
requirements: You must live in the home you apply for support for
The home must be approved for year-round use
You must have legal residence in Norway
Your income must be below a certain limit
Your housing costs must be above a certain limit
bostotte.stepsTitle: How to apply for housing allowance

steps.title: Go to husbanken.no
steps.description: Open the browser and type husbanken.no in the address bar. Press Enter.
steps.tip: You can also search Google for "Husbanken housing allowance".

steps.title: Find the application form
steps.description: On the front page you'll find "Housing allowance" in the menu. Click on "Apply for housing allowance" or "Log in and apply".
steps.tip: The application button is usually clearly visible on the front page.

steps.title: Log in with BankID
steps.description: You must log in to apply. Use BankID on mobile or code device. Follow the instructions on screen.
steps.warning: Don't have BankID? You can get help at the municipality service office.

steps.title: Fill out the application
steps.description: The application form automatically retrieves information about you. Check that everything is correct. Fill in your housing costs (rent, common costs, etc.).
steps.tip: Have the rental contract or documentation of housing costs ready.

steps.title: Document housing costs
steps.description: Upload rental contract or other documentation of your housing costs. Take a photo with your phone if you don't have a scanner.
steps.warning: Without documentation, the application may be rejected.

steps.title: Submit the application
steps.description: Review the application and check that everything is correct. Click "Submit" when you're done.
steps.tip: You receive confirmation by email or in digital mailbox.

steps.title: Wait for response
steps.description: Husbanken processes your application. Response usually comes within a few weeks. You can monitor status in the application portal.
steps.tip: Housing allowance is applied for monthly, but you don't need to submit a new application - it renews automatically.

tips: Apply as early as possible in the month - the deadline is the 25th of each month
You get a response around the 10th of the following month
Report changes in income or housing costs
You can apply retroactively if you forgot to apply
The municipality can help you with the application if you need it

startlan.title: Apply for starter loan
startlan.description: Loan from the municipality for those who can't get a loan from a regular bank
startlan.longDescription: Starter loan is a loan from the municipality for people who have problems getting a loan from a regular bank. It can be used to buy a home or refinance expensive debt.
startlan.whatIsText1: Starter loan is a loan from your municipality financed by Husbanken. It's meant for those with stable income but who can't get a loan from a regular bank.
startlan.whatIsText2: The starter loan can cover all or part of the purchase price for a home. The interest rate is favorable and you can get long repayment time.
startlan.requirementsTitle: Who can get a starter loan?
requirements: You must have long-term problems getting a loan from a regular bank
You must have the ability to service the loan over time
You must need housing (first-time buyers, families with children, single providers)
You must be able to document your income
You must have tried to get a loan from a regular bank first
startlan.stepsTitle: How to apply for starter loan

steps.title: Check if you can get a bank loan
steps.description: Contact a bank and ask if they can give you a mortgage. If they say no, ask for written confirmation of the rejection.
steps.tip: The rejection from the bank is important documentation in your application.

steps.title: Find the municipality's application form
steps.description: Go to your municipality's website and search for "starter loan". Most municipalities have electronic application forms.
steps.tip: Many municipalities use husbanken.no or altinn.no for applications.

steps.title: Log in and start the application
steps.description: Log in with BankID. Fill in information about yourself, your finances and what type of home you're applying for a loan for.
steps.warning: Be honest about your finances - the municipality checks the information.

steps.title: Document your finances
steps.description: Upload latest payslip, tax return, rejection from bank, and any documentation of debt.
steps.tip: The better documentation, the faster processing.

steps.title: Describe housing needs
steps.description: Explain why you need housing and what type of home you're looking for. If you've found a home, include information about it.
steps.tip: The municipality assesses whether the home is suitable for you and your finances.

steps.title: Submit the application
steps.description: Review all information and click "Submit". You receive confirmation that the application has been received.
steps.tip: Keep the receipt and any reference numbers.

steps.title: Wait for response
steps.description: The municipality processes your application. This may take several weeks. They may contact you for more information.
steps.warning: Processing time varies from municipality to municipality.

tips: Start the process early - processing time can be long
Be realistic about what you can afford
You may get starter loan together with grants in some cases
The municipality can help you find a suitable home
You can apply for payment deferral if your finances change

kommunalBolig.title: Apply for municipal housing
kommunalBolig.description: Rent housing from the municipality if you cannot find housing yourself
kommunalBolig.longDescription: Municipal housing is an offer to people who cannot find housing on their own. The municipality owns the homes and rents them out at reduced prices.
kommunalBolig.whatIsText1: Municipal housing is homes that the municipality owns and rents to people who need help finding housing. Rent is often lower than on the private market.
kommunalBolig.whatIsText2: There is a limited number of municipal homes, so there may be a waiting list. The municipality prioritizes those with the greatest need.
requirements: You must be without housing or at risk of losing your home
You must have tried to find housing yourself without success
You must have legal residence in Norway
You must usually have lived in the municipality for a certain time
Financial, social or health conditions make it difficult to find housing
kommunalBolig.stepsTitle: How to apply for municipal housing

steps.title: Find the municipality's application form
steps.description: Go to your municipality's website. Search for "municipal housing" or "housing". Find the application form.
steps.tip: You can also call the municipality service office for help.

steps.title: Gather documentation
steps.description: You need documentation of income, any debt, and why you need municipal housing. Gather this before you start the application.
steps.tip: Medical certificate or statement from NAV can strengthen the application.

steps.title: Fill out the application
steps.description: Fill in all fields in the application form. Describe your situation as well as you can.
steps.warning: Incomplete application can delay processing.

steps.title: Describe housing needs
steps.description: Explain what kind of housing you need (number of rooms, location, accessibility). Describe any special needs.
steps.tip: If you have children, state age and any visitation.

steps.title: Upload documentation
steps.description: Upload all documents that support your application. The more documentation, the easier it is for the municipality to assess the application.
steps.warning: Missing documentation can lead to rejection.

steps.title: Submit the application
steps.description: Check that everything is filled in and submit the application. You receive confirmation that it has been received.
steps.tip: Note the date you submitted the application.

steps.title: Wait for response
steps.description: The municipality processes the application. Processing time varies. You may be called in for a meeting.
steps.tip: You can contact the municipality to hear about the status of the application.

tips: Apply as early as possible - there can be a long waiting time
Keep the municipality updated if your situation changes
You can appeal rejection to the municipality's appeals board
NAV can help with temporary housing while you wait
You can apply for housing allowance to help with rent

studielan.title: Apply for student loan
studielan.description: Loans and grants from Lanekassen for education
studielan.longDescription: Lanekassen provides loans and grants to students. Here you learn how to apply and what you need.
studielan.whatIsText1: Student loan is money you borrow from Lanekassen to cover expenses while studying. You pay back after finishing your education.
studielan.whatIsText2: Parts of the loan can be converted to grant if you complete your education and don't earn above a certain limit.
studielan.requirementsTitle: Who can get a student loan?
requirements: You must be admitted to an approved education
You must be registered as a student
You must take credits/be an active student
You must have valid residence permit in Norway (if not Norwegian citizen)
studielan.stepsTitle: How to apply for student loan

steps.title: Go to lanekassen.no
steps.description: Open the browser and type lanekassen.no. Click on "Log in" in the top right corner.
steps.tip: You can also search Google for "Lanekassen apply loan".

steps.title: Log in with BankID
steps.description: Choose BankID on mobile or code device. Follow the instructions to log in.
steps.warning: Don't have BankID? You can order it at your bank.

steps.title: Find the application form
steps.description: After logging in, click on "Apply for loan and grant" or "Application". Select the correct academic year.
steps.tip: The application usually opens in mid-March for the fall semester.

steps.title: Select education
steps.description: Search for your school and education. The system shows what you can get in loans and grants based on the education.
steps.tip: If the education doesn't appear, check that you've selected the correct academic year.

steps.title: Fill in personal information
steps.description: Check that your contact information is correct. Provide account number for payment.
steps.warning: Wrong account number means delayed payment!

steps.title: Choose how much to borrow
steps.description: You can choose to borrow the full amount or less. Check what can become a grant.
steps.tip: Only borrow what you need - you'll pay it back later.

steps.title: Submit the application
steps.description: Review the application and click "Submit". You receive confirmation by email.
steps.tip: You can follow status in "My page" at Lanekassen.

tips: Apply well before semester start
Report changes (e.g. interrupted studies, work on the side)
Check deadlines for conversion to grant
You can apply for travel support if you study far from home
If you live with other students you can share housing costs

stipend.title: Apply for grant
stipend.description: Get parts of the loan converted to grant
stipend.longDescription: Lanekassen can convert parts of your loan to grant. Here you learn how it works.
stipend.whatIsText1: Grant is money you receive that you don't need to pay back. Lanekassen first gives loans, which can become grants if you meet the requirements.
stipend.whatIsText2: Conversion to grant happens automatically if you complete credits and don't earn too much.
requirements: You must complete the credits you received support for
You must not earn above the income limit
You must not have too much wealth
The education must be approved by Lanekassen

steps.title: Apply for loan as usual
steps.description: You first apply for loan and grant. The money is paid out as a loan initially.
steps.tip: It's the same application for loan and grant.

steps.title: Complete the credits
steps.description: Take exams and pass the subjects you received support for. Lanekassen automatically checks with the school.
steps.warning: If you don't pass, the loan remains a loan.

steps.title: Stay under the income limit
steps.description: You can work alongside studies, but not earn above the limit. Check current limits on lanekassen.no.
steps.tip: The limit is approx. NOK 200,000 per year (check updated amount).

steps.title: Conversion happens automatically
steps.description: When Lanekassen has received your results, they automatically convert the loan to grant.
steps.tip: You can see status on "My page" at Lanekassen.

steps.title: Check the result
steps.description: Log in to lanekassen.no and see how much has been converted. You also get a message in the inbox.
steps.warning: If something is wrong, contact Lanekassen as soon as possible.

tips: Conversion happens the year after you took exams
If you earn too much one year, you can apply for exception in special circumstances
Housing grant you can get regardless of income if you live away from parents
If you complete on time, you can get final loan converted to grant

tilbakebetaling.title: Repaying student loan
tilbakebetaling.description: Pay back student loan and apply for deferment
tilbakebetaling.longDescription: When you finish your education, the loan must be paid back. Here you learn how it works and what you can do if you struggle.
tilbakebetaling.whatIsText1: You start paying back the student loan about 7 months after finishing your education. You receive a letter from Lanekassen with a payment plan.
tilbakebetaling.whatIsText2: The loan is usually paid over 20 years with fixed monthly amounts. You can choose to pay faster or apply for deferment.
options: Apply for payment deferment if you struggle
Apply for interest exemption with low income

steps.title: Wait for invoice
steps.description: About 7 months after finishing education you get your first invoice. It arrives in Digipost or as a letter.
steps.tip: Check that Lanekassen has correct address and email.

steps.title: Set up AvtaleGiro
steps.description: Log in to lanekassen.no and select "Payment". Set up AvtaleGiro for automatic payment.
steps.tip: With AvtaleGiro you don't have to remember to pay each month.

steps.title: Check the payment plan
steps.description: See how much you will pay and for how long. You can change the repayment period if you wish.
steps.warning: Longer repayment period = more interest in total.

steps.title: Pay on time
steps.description: Pay the invoice before the due date. If you don't pay, late interest and fees accrue.
steps.warning: Missing payment can lead to collection.

steps.title: Apply for deferment if necessary
steps.description: Short on money? Log in and apply for payment deferment. You can get up to 36 months deferment.
steps.tip: Apply BEFORE the due date to avoid fees.

tips: You can get interest exemption if you earn below a certain limit
In case of unemployment or illness you can apply for deferment
You can pay extra when you can afford it
Lanekassen sends reminders before due date - check inbox
Contact Lanekassen early if you struggle with payment

pass.title: Order passport
pass.description: How to order new or renew your passport
pass.longDescription: Passport is an important ID document. Here you learn how to order a new passport or renew the old one.
pass.whatIsText1: Passport is a travel document that confirms your identity. You need a passport to travel to countries outside the Nordic region.
pass.whatIsText2: Norwegian passport is valid for 10 years for adults and 5 years for children under 16.
requirements: Valid ID (old passport, driver's license or bank card with photo)
Payment (approx. NOK 570 for adults, NOK 270 for children)
Appointment booking with the police
Old passport (if you have one)

steps.title: Book appointment with the police
steps.description: Go to politiet.no and select "Book appointment". Select "Passport" and find available time at the nearest passport office.
steps.tip: During holiday season there can be long waiting time - book well in advance!

steps.title: Show up at agreed time
steps.description: Bring valid ID and old passport. The police take a new photo and fingerprints.
steps.warning: If you arrive late, you lose the appointment and must book a new one.

steps.title: Pay for the passport
steps.description: You pay by card at the passport office. The price is approx. NOK 570 for adults.
steps.tip: Check updated prices on politiet.no.

steps.title: Wait for the passport
steps.description: The passport is sent to your home by mail. It usually takes 10-14 days.
steps.tip: You can track the shipment on politiet.no with your reference number.

steps.title: Pick up or receive the passport
steps.description: Most people receive the passport by mail. Some places you can pick it up at the passport office.
steps.warning: Check that all information is correct when you receive the passport!

tips: Book appointment early - especially before summer there is long waiting time
Children must bring both parents or authorization
The passport must be valid for at least 6 months for many destinations
Lost passport must be reported to police before you can get a new one
You can get emergency passport same day in special cases

forerkort.title: Renew driver's license
forerkort.description: How to renew or order driver's license
forerkort.longDescription: Driver's license must be renewed after a certain time. Here you learn how to do it.
forerkort.whatIsText1: Driver's license is both proof that you're allowed to drive and a valid ID card. It must be renewed regularly.
forerkort.whatIsText2: Driver's license for car (class B) is valid for 15 years, but must be renewed more often after turning 75.
requirements: Valid ID
Health certificate if you're over 75
Payment (approx. NOK 250-400)
New passport photo (can be taken at the traffic station)

steps.title: Book appointment at Statens vegvesen
steps.description: Go to vegvesen.no and select "Book appointment". Find "Driver's license" and select nearest traffic station.
steps.tip: You can also call 22 07 30 00 to book an appointment.

steps.title: Show up with ID
steps.description: Bring valid ID. A new photo is taken at the station.
steps.warning: Old driver's license must be handed in.

steps.title: Pay the fee
steps.description: You pay by card at the traffic station. The price varies by type of driver's license.
steps.tip: Check prices on vegvesen.no before showing up.

steps.title: Wait for new driver's license
steps.description: The new driver's license is sent by mail. It takes about 1-2 weeks.
steps.tip: You get a temporary driver's license that is valid while you wait.

steps.title: Activate driver's license
steps.description: When you receive the driver's license, it's ready to use. Check that all information is correct.
steps.warning: Report errors immediately!

tips: Renew driver's license before it expires - driving with expired license is not allowed
If you're over 75, you need health certificate from doctor
Lost driver's license can be replaced for a fee
You can check validity on vegvesen.no
EU driver's license is valid throughout Europe

idKort.title: National ID card
idKort.description: Order national ID card with or without travel rights
idKort.longDescription: National ID card is an alternative to passport and driver's license as identification. It can also be used as travel document in Europe.
idKort.whatIsText1: National ID card is an official ID document issued by the police. It comes in two variants: with and without travel rights.
idKort.whatIsText2: With travel rights you can use the card instead of passport in the EEA area. The card is valid for 5 years.
types: With travel rights (approx. NOK 570) - can be used as travel document in EEA
Without travel rights (approx. NOK 490) - only identification in Norway

steps.title: Book appointment with the police
steps.description: Go to politiet.no and select "Book appointment". Select "ID card" and find nearest police station that issues ID cards.
steps.tip: Not all police stations issue ID cards - check the list on politiet.no.

steps.title: Show up at agreed time
steps.description: Bring valid ID (passport, driver's license or other approved ID). The police take photo and fingerprints.
steps.warning: For ID card with travel rights you must have Norwegian national ID number.

steps.title: Choose type of ID card
steps.description: Choose if you want ID card with or without travel rights. With travel rights you can travel in EEA without passport.
steps.tip: Travel rights is recommended if you travel in Europe.

steps.title: Pay the fee
steps.description: Pay by card on site. The price depends on type of ID card.
steps.tip: Check updated prices on politiet.no.

steps.title: Wait for the ID card
steps.description: The ID card is sent by mail. It usually takes 10-14 days.
steps.tip: You can track the shipment with your reference number.

tips: The ID card is smaller than passport and fits in wallet
You can have both passport and ID card
ID card with travel rights is accepted as ID everywhere in Norway
Children can also get ID card
In case of loss you must report to police

smarttelefon.title: Using smartphone
smarttelefon.description: Learn basic use of iPhone and Android phones
smarttelefon.longDescription: The smartphone is the key to digital Norway. Here you learn the most basic things - from turning on the phone to using apps.
smarttelefon.beforeYouStartText: A smartphone is a small computer you can hold in your hand. It's used for calling, sending messages, taking photos, and using apps (programs) like BankID, Vipps and more.

steps.title: Turn on the phone
steps.description: Hold the large button on the side of the phone for a few seconds. The screen will light up. If the phone has been off for a long time, it may take a while.
steps.tip: Most phones have the power button on the right side.

steps.title: Unlock the phone
steps.description: When the phone is on, you need to unlock it. Swipe up on the screen (drag your finger upward). You may need to enter a code or use fingerprint.
steps.tip: The code is usually 4 or 6 digits that you choose yourself.

steps.title: Understand the home screen
steps.description: The home screen is the first thing you see. Here the apps (programs) are displayed as small square icons. Tap once on an icon to open the app.
steps.tip: Swipe left or right to see more pages with apps.

steps.title: Call someone
steps.description: Find and tap the phone icon (usually green with a handset). Enter the number you want to call. Press the green button to call. Press red to hang up.
steps.tip: You can save numbers under "Contacts" so you don't have to remember them.

steps.title: Send a text message
steps.description: Find and tap the messages icon (usually looks like a speech bubble). Tap plus or "New message". Enter the number or select a contact. Write the message and tap send.
steps.tip: The keyboard appears when you need to write. Tap the letters one by one.

steps.title: Take a photo
steps.description: Find and tap the camera icon. Point the phone at what you want to photograph. Tap the large round button on the screen. The photo is saved automatically.
steps.tip: You find the photos in the "Photos" or "Gallery" app.

steps.title: Connect to Wi-Fi (wireless internet)
steps.description: Go to Settings (gear icon). Tap Wi-Fi. Select your network (it's often named the same as your router). Enter the password.
steps.tip: The Wi-Fi password is often on a label on the router/box from your internet provider.

steps.title: Download an app
steps.description: Open App Store (iPhone) or Google Play (Android). Search for the app you want, e.g. "BankID" or "Vipps". Tap "Get" or "Install". Wait for the app to download.
steps.warning: Be careful what you download. Stick to known apps from safe providers.

tips: Charge the phone every night - then it's always ready to use
If something freezes, try turning the phone off and on again
Don't be afraid to try - you can rarely break anything
Ask family or friends for help setting up the phone first time
Set large text in settings if you find the text too small

nettleser.title: Using web browser
nettleser.description: Learn to open websites and find information on the internet
nettleser.longDescription: The browser is your window to the internet. Here you learn how to use it to visit websites, search for information and navigate safely.
nettleser.whatIsText: A web browser is a program that lets you view websites. The most common are Safari (on iPhone), Chrome (on Android and computers) and Edge (on Windows computers).

steps.title: Open the browser
steps.description: Find the browser icon on your phone or computer. Safari has a compass icon, Chrome has a colorful circle, and Edge has a blue "e".
steps.tip: On your phone you often find the browser on the home screen.

steps.title: Understand the address bar
steps.description: At the top of the browser is the address bar - a long white box. Here you type the address of the website you want to visit, e.g. "nav.no" or "helsenorge.no".
steps.tip: You don't need to type "www." before the address anymore.

steps.title: Visit a website
steps.description: Tap on the address bar. Type the address you want to visit, e.g. "vg.no". Press the Enter key (or "Go" on phone).
steps.tip: Be accurate with the address - small errors can lead you to the wrong site.

steps.title: Search on Google
steps.description: You can also search for things. Type what you're looking for in the address bar, e.g. "NAV opening hours" or "weather in Oslo". Press Enter. Google shows you relevant results.
steps.tip: Feel free to write full questions, like "how much does it cost to renew passport"

steps.title: Click on links
steps.description: Websites have links - text that is blue and underlined. When you click (or tap) on a link, you go to a new page.
steps.tip: To go back to the previous page, press the arrow pointing left (back button).

steps.title: Use the back button
steps.description: In the top left you find an arrow pointing left. Press it to go back to the page you just were on. You can press multiple times to go further back.
steps.tip: On your phone you can often swipe from the left edge to go back.

steps.title: Close the browser
steps.description: On phone: Swipe up from the bottom (iPhone) or press the square button (Android) to close. On computer: Click the X in the top right corner.

safetyTips: Always look at the address at the top - real nav.no has exactly that address, not "nav-login.com" or similar
Type addresses yourself instead of clicking links in email
Look for the padlock icon by the address - it means the site is secure
If something seems strange or too good to be true, be careful

videosamtale.title: Using video calls
videosamtale.description: Learn to use Zoom, Teams and FaceTime to talk to family and doctor
videosamtale.longDescription: Video calls let you see and talk to people even if they're far away. Perfect for staying in touch with family or having doctor appointments from home.
whyUseList: See grandchildren and family who live far away
Have doctor appointment or NAV meeting from home
Participate in courses and events without traveling
Get help from family with technical problems - they can see your screen

apps.name: FaceTime
apps.desc: Built into iPhone/iPad. Easiest to use with other Apple users.

apps.name: Zoom
apps.desc: Popular app for meetings. Used by many municipalities and health services.

apps.name: Teams
apps.desc: Microsoft's app. Often used by NAV and workplaces.

apps.name: WhatsApp
apps.desc: Simple video for family and friends. Many already have it.

videosamtale.stepsTitle: How to join a video call

steps.title: Get an invitation
steps.description: You usually receive a link by email or SMS. The link looks like a web address and often starts with "zoom.us" or "teams.microsoft.com".
steps.tip: Save the email or message so you can find the link again.

steps.title: Click the link when it's time
steps.description: A few minutes before the meeting starts, click the link. You'll be asked if you want to open the app or browser. Choose "Open" or "Join".
steps.tip: Feel free to test sound and video before the meeting by clicking the link a bit early.

steps.title: Grant access to camera and microphone
steps.description: The app asks for permission to use camera and microphone. Press "Allow" on both. Without this, others cannot see or hear you.
steps.warning: If you can't get in, check that you've granted permissions in settings.

steps.title: Check that you can see yourself
steps.description: Before entering the meeting, you often see yourself in a small window. Check that the lighting is good and the camera captures your face.
steps.tip: Sit with the window or lamp in front of you, not behind - then others see you better.

steps.title: Enter the meeting
steps.description: Click "Join" or "Join Meeting". You now enter the meeting and can see other participants.
steps.tip: If you're early, you may need to wait for the host to start the meeting.

steps.title: Turn sound and video on/off
steps.description: At the bottom of the screen you find buttons for microphone and camera. Press the microphone icon to turn sound on/off. Press the camera icon to turn video on/off.
steps.tip: Turn off the microphone when you're not speaking - then others don't hear background noise.

steps.title: End the call
steps.description: When the call is finished, press the red "End" or "Leave" button. You exit the meeting.
steps.tip: Remember to say goodbye before ending!

troubleshooting.solution: Check that the microphone is not muted (no line through icon). Check the volume.
Check your internet connection. Try closing other apps.
Move closer to Wi-Fi router or turn off your own camera for better flow.
Try clicking the link again. Check that the app is updated.

passordHjelp.title: Password and login
passordHjelp.description: Learn to create good passwords and what to do when you've forgotten it
passordHjelp.longDescription: Passwords protect your personal information. Here you learn to create safe passwords and what to do if you forget them.
passordHjelp.whyImportantText: Your password is like the key to your house - it keeps strangers out. A bad password makes it easy for scammers to steal your money or identity.
passordHjelp.goodPasswordTitle: How to create a good password
goodPasswordTips: Use at least 12 characters - the longer, the better
Mix upper and lower case letters, numbers and symbols
Don't use your name, birth date or "123456"
Feel free to use a sentence you remember: "MyCatIsNamedFluffy2!"
Use different passwords on important services (bank, NAV, email)

forgotPasswordSteps.title: Find the "Forgot password" link
forgotPasswordSteps.description: On the login page you often find a link that says "Forgot password?", "Reset password" or "Need help?". Click on it.
forgotPasswordSteps.tip: The link is usually below the field where you type password.

forgotPasswordSteps.title: Enter email or phone number
forgotPasswordSteps.description: You'll be asked to enter the email address or phone number you registered with. Enter it exactly.
forgotPasswordSteps.tip: Check that you're using the correct email address - the one you usually log in with.

forgotPasswordSteps.title: Check your email
forgotPasswordSteps.description: You receive an email or SMS with a link to create a new password. It may take a few minutes. Check spam folder if you can't find it.
forgotPasswordSteps.warning: The link is valid for a short time - often only 1 hour. Use it quickly.

forgotPasswordSteps.title: Create new password
forgotPasswordSteps.description: Click the link in the email. Enter a new, strong password. You must type it twice to confirm.
forgotPasswordSteps.tip: Write down the new password in a safe place until you remember it.

forgotPasswordSteps.title: Log in with new password
forgotPasswordSteps.description: Go back to the login page and log in with the new password. Now you're in again!
forgotPasswordSteps.tip: Consider writing the password in a notebook you keep safely at home.

passordHjelp.bankidNoteText: BankID password cannot be reset yourself online. If you've forgotten the BankID code, you must contact your bank to get a new one. They will help you.

faHjelp.title: Where to get help
faHjelp.description: Find places that offer free computer help in your area
faHjelp.longDescription: You don't have to be alone with digital things. Here you find an overview of places and people who can help you - often completely free.
faHjelp.introText: Many organizations and volunteers offer free help to people who find digital things difficult. Here are some good places to start:

helpSources.name: Seniornett Norge
helpSources.description: Volunteer organization that helps seniors with digital things. They have local groups across the country that hold courses and provide help.

helpSources.name: Your local library
helpSources.description: Many libraries offer free computer help. Some have regular "computer hours" where you can get help with most things.
helpSources.howToContact: Call or visit your library and ask if they offer computer help

helpSources.name: Volunteer center
helpSources.description: Local volunteer centers often have volunteers who can help with computers and phones at your home.

helpSources.name: Family and friends
helpSources.description: Many have children, grandchildren, neighbors or friends who can help. Most think it's nice to help!
helpSources.howToContact: Just ask - most say yes with pleasure

helpSources.name: NAV
helpSources.description: If you need help using NAV's services, you can get guidance at your local NAV office.
helpSources.howToContact: Call 55 55 33 33 or visit the NAV office

tips: Write down your questions before meeting the helper
Ask them to show you slowly - you should learn yourself, not just watch
Don't be embarrassed - everyone was a beginner once
Take notes or ask to have instructions written down
Ask if you can call if you forget how to do it

ordbok.title: Dictionary
ordbok.subtitle: Here we explain difficult words and expressions you encounter on public websites.
ordbok.searchPlaceholder: Type a word you're wondering about...
ordbok.missingWordText: Send us an email at kontakt@lettdigital.no if there's a word you'd like explained, and we'll add it!

terms.definition: Work Assessment Allowance - money you can receive from NAV if you cannot work due to illness or injury and need help returning to work.
terms.example: After 1 year on sick pay, you can apply for AAP.

terms.definition: Child benefit - money all parents automatically receive from NAV for children under 18 years old.
terms.example: Child benefit is paid on the 10th of each month.

terms.definition: Unemployment benefits - money you can receive from NAV when you have lost your job or are temporarily laid off.
terms.example: Unemployment benefits are approximately 62% of your salary.

terms.definition: Father's quota - the portion of parental leave reserved for the father or co-mother. Cannot be transferred to the mother.
terms.example: The father's quota is 15 weeks.

terms.definition: The National Insurance base amount - an amount used to calculate many benefits from NAV. Adjusted annually.
terms.example: In 2024, G is approximately NOK 118,620.

terms.definition: Cash-for-care benefit - support for parents who care for children at home instead of using daycare.
terms.example: You can receive cash-for-care benefit for children between 1-2 years old.

terms.definition: Employment status form - a form you submit to NAV every 14 days to report whether you have worked, been sick, or applied for jobs.
terms.example: Submit your employment status form to receive your unemployment benefits.

terms.definition: Mother's quota - the portion of parental leave reserved for the mother. Cannot be transferred to the father.
terms.example: The mother's quota is 15 weeks.

terms.definition: Temporarily laid off - temporarily released from work because your employer has no work for you, but you are still employed.
terms.example: Many were temporarily laid off during the coronavirus pandemic.

terms.definition: Sick pay - money that replaces your income when you are ill and cannot work.
terms.example: You can receive sick pay for up to 1 year.

terms.definition: Disability benefit - a permanent benefit for those with reduced work capacity due to illness or injury.
terms.example: Disability benefit can be full or partial.

terms.definition: Benefit - money or services you can receive from NAV or other public agencies.
terms.example: Unemployment benefits are a benefit from NAV.

terms.definition: Deduction - expenses that are subtracted from your income before tax is calculated. Reduces your tax.
terms.example: Interest expenses on home loans are a common deduction.

terms.definition: Back taxes - additional tax you must pay because you paid too little during the year.
terms.example: Back taxes over NOK 1,000 are divided into two installments.

terms.definition: Tax card - a document that tells your employer how much tax should be deducted from your salary.
terms.example: You receive a new tax card in December each year.

terms.definition: Tax return - an overview of income and deductions you must submit to the Tax Administration each year. Previously called 'selvangivelse'.
terms.example: The deadline for the tax return is April 30th.

terms.definition: Tax settlement - the calculation that shows whether you will receive money back or must pay back taxes.
terms.example: The tax settlement usually arrives in June.

terms.definition: Table number - the code on your tax card that determines how much tax is deducted from your salary.
terms.example: Table number 7100 is standard for most people.

terms.definition: Advance tax - tax that self-employed individuals pay in advance four times a year.
terms.example: Advance tax is due on March 15, June 15, September 15, and December 15.

terms.definition: Wealth tax - tax on assets you own above a certain amount (property, shares, bank deposits minus debt).
terms.example: Wealth tax applies to wealth above approximately NOK 1.7 million.

terms.definition: Blue prescription - a prescription for medicines for chronic diseases where the state covers most of the cost.
terms.example: Diabetes medication is available on blue prescription.

terms.definition: Co-payment - the portion of the cost you must pay yourself, for example at the doctor.
terms.example: The co-payment at your regular doctor is approximately NOK 160.

terms.definition: Discharge summary - a summary written by the doctor after treatment is completed.
terms.example: The discharge summary is sent to your regular doctor.

terms.definition: Regular doctor (GP) - the doctor assigned to you who should be your permanent doctor for common health problems.
terms.example: You can change your regular doctor up to twice per year.

terms.definition: Exemption card - a card that gives you free healthcare services when you have paid enough in co-payments (the exemption limit).
terms.example: The exemption limit is approximately NOK 3,040 (2024).

terms.definition: Referral - a letter from your regular doctor that gives you the right to treatment at a specialist or hospital.
terms.example: You need a referral to see a specialist.

terms.definition: White prescription - a regular prescription where you pay all or part of the cost yourself.
terms.example: Antibiotics are often on white prescription.

terms.definition: Summary Care Record - a digital overview of important health information shared between healthcare services.
terms.example: The Summary Care Record shows medications and allergies.

terms.definition: Emergency room / Urgent care - emergency medical help when your regular doctor is closed. Call 116 117.
terms.example: The emergency room is open around the clock.

terms.definition: Patient record - documentation of all healthcare you have received. You have the right to read your own record.
terms.example: You can read your patient record on Helsenorge.

terms.definition: Sick note - a document from the doctor confirming that you are ill and cannot work.
terms.example: The doctor sends the sick note electronically to NAV.

terms.definition: Altinn - a website where you can submit forms and documents to public authorities.
terms.example: You can find your tax return on Altinn.

terms.definition: App - a program you download to your phone.
terms.example: Download the NAV app from the App Store or Google Play.

terms.definition: BankID - a digital identity you use to log in to websites and sign documents. You get BankID from your bank.
terms.example: Log in with BankID on your mobile.

terms.definition: Digital mailbox - a digital mailbox where you can receive letters from public agencies and businesses.
terms.example: Your tax settlement arrives in Digipost.

terms.definition: ID-porten - the system that handles login to public websites like NAV, the Tax Administration, and Helsenorge.
terms.example: ID-porten is common for all public services.

terms.definition: MinID - a simpler login solution than BankID, but does not provide access to all services.
terms.example: MinID does not work for the tax return.

terms.definition: Web browser - a program for viewing websites, such as Google Chrome, Safari, or Edge.
terms.example: Open the browser to go to nav.no.

terms.definition: Direct debit - automatic payment of regular bills like electricity, insurance, and rent.
terms.example: With direct debit, the bill is paid automatically on the due date.

terms.definition: Electronic invoice - a digital invoice that goes directly into your online bank, so you don't have to enter numbers.
terms.example: Turn on electronic invoices to get bills automatically in your online bank.

terms.definition: Due date - the last day a bill must be paid without an extra fee.
terms.example: The due date is shown at the top of the invoice.

terms.definition: Debt collection - when a company sends your bill to a collection agency because you haven't paid.
terms.example: Pay before debt collection to avoid extra fees and payment remarks.

terms.definition: KID number - a number sequence on invoices that identifies your payment. Important to enter correctly.
terms.example: The KID number is on the invoice, usually 15-25 digits.

terms.definition: Online banking - the bank's internet service where you can pay bills, check your balance, and transfer money.
terms.example: You log into online banking with BankID.

terms.definition: Balance - how much money you have in your account right now.
terms.example: Check your balance in online banking before paying a large bill.

terms.definition: Vipps - a Norwegian payment app for sending money to friends, paying in stores, and splitting bills.
terms.example: Over 4 million Norwegians use Vipps.

terms.definition: Password manager - a program that securely stores all your passwords, so you only need to remember one master password.
terms.example: Bitwarden and 1Password are popular password managers.

terms.definition: Phishing - fraud attempts via fake emails or messages that try to trick you into giving away personal information.
terms.example: An email pretending to be from your bank could be phishing. Never click on links you're unsure about.

terms.definition: Fraud / Scam - when someone tries to trick you for money or personal information.
terms.example: Never call back unknown numbers asking for personal information - it could be a scam.

terms.definition: Two-factor authentication (2FA) - extra security where you need both a password and a code from your phone to log in.
