terms.example: Turn on two-factor authentication for extra protection of your email.

terms.definition: Housing allowance - financial support from Husbanken to pay rent or housing expenses for those with low income.
terms.example: Housing allowance is paid around the 10th of each month.

terms.definition: The Norwegian State Housing Bank - a state bank that provides loans and grants for housing, and manages the housing allowance scheme.
terms.example: Apply for housing allowance through Husbanken at husbanken.no.

terms.definition: Municipal housing - housing owned by the municipality that is rented out to those who have difficulty obtaining housing themselves.
terms.example: Municipal housing often has lower rent than private landlords.

terms.definition: Starter loan - a loan from the municipality for those who cannot get a regular home loan from the bank.
terms.example: Starter loans can help first-time buyers who don't have enough equity.

terms.definition: The Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund - a state agency that provides student loans and grants for education in Norway and abroad.
terms.example: Apply for grants and loans from Lanekassen at lanekassen.no.

terms.definition: Grant / Scholarship - money for education that you do not need to pay back.
terms.example: You can get up to 40% of the support as a grant if you complete your studies.

terms.definition: Student loan - a loan from Lanekassen to cover expenses during education. Must be repaid after studies.
terms.example: Repayment of the student loan usually starts 7 months after completing education.

terms.definition: The National Population Register - a public register of everyone living in Norway with addresses and personal information.
terms.example: Report your move to the Population Register within 8 days.

terms.definition: National ID card - a Norwegian ID card with photo that can be used as identification in Norway and for travel within the EU/EEA.
terms.example: The National ID card is not a valid travel document outside the EU/EEA.

terms.definition: Passport - an official travel document that confirms your identity and Norwegian citizenship.
terms.example: You must have a valid passport to travel outside Europe.

terms.definition: Personal identification number - the 11 digits that uniquely identify you in Norway (birth date + 5 digits).
terms.example: Your personal identification number is used when logging in with BankID and at the doctor.

terms.definition: Old-age pension - monthly payment from the state when you become a pensioner. Can be withdrawn from age 62, but the later you start, the more you get.
terms.example: You can check how much old-age pension you will receive at nav.no/pensjon.

terms.definition: Contractual Early Retirement Pension (AFP) - supplementary pension for employees in companies with collective agreements. Provides lifelong extra payment alongside old-age pension.
terms.example: AFP gives you the opportunity to retire earlier with more money.

terms.definition: Guarantee pension - minimum pension that ensures everyone a certain income in old age, even if you have worked little.
terms.example: Guarantee pension requires that you have lived in Norway for at least 5 years.

terms.definition: Pension balance - the sum of all your pension points throughout your working life. Determines how much pension you receive.
terms.example: You can see your pension balance on 'Din pensjon' (Your Pension) at nav.no.

terms.definition: Pension points - points you earn each year based on your income. Used to calculate old-age pension.
terms.example: You earn pension points on all income up to 7.1 G.

terms.definition: Survivor's pension - financial support for those who have lost a spouse or cohabitant with shared children.
terms.example: Survivor's pension can be given for up to 3 years, or until you get a new partner.

terms.definition: Occupational pension - pension from your employer, in addition to old-age pension from NAV. Also called OTP (mandatory occupational pension).
terms.example: All employers must save at least 2% for occupational pension for employees.

terms.definition: Withdrawal rate - what percentage of your pension you choose to withdraw. You can withdraw 20%, 40%, 50%, 60%, 80%, or 100%.
terms.example: With a 50% withdrawal rate, you receive half your pension and can work alongside it.

terms.definition: Update - a new version of an app or phone that fixes errors and adds security. Important to install!
terms.example: Check Settings - Software Update to update your phone.

terms.definition: Wi-Fi - wireless internet from a router. Free to use at home, at the library, or at cafes.
terms.example: Connect to Wi-Fi to save mobile data.

terms.definition: Mobile data - internet via your phone subscription. Costs money and often has a limit.
terms.example: Use Wi-Fi at home to save mobile data for when you're out.

terms.definition: Screenshot - a picture of what is shown on your screen. Useful for showing error messages to others.
terms.example: Take a screenshot with side button + volume up (iPhone) or power + volume down (Android).

terms.definition: Web browser - a program for visiting websites. Safari (iPhone), Chrome (Android), and Edge (PC) are common.
terms.example: Open the browser and type nav.no in the address bar.

terms.definition: Download - retrieving a file or app from the internet to your phone or PC.
terms.example: Downloaded files can usually be found in the Files app or Downloads folder.

terms.definition: Settings - the place on your phone where you can change language, font size, Wi-Fi, sound, and more.
terms.example: Go to Settings to increase the font size on your phone.

terms.definition: Notification - a message that appears on your phone to alert you to something, such as a new SMS or reminder.
terms.example: You can turn off notifications for apps that disturb you in Settings.

terms.definition: Home screen - the main screen on your phone where all your app icons are located.
terms.example: Press the home button to return to the home screen.

terms.definition: Contacts - a list of phone numbers and names of people you know, stored on your phone.
terms.example: Add a new number to Contacts so you can see who is calling.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Here you'll find answers to the most common questions about public digital services.
faq.noAnswer: Didn't find an answer to your question?
faq.contactAgencies: You can contact the agencies directly for more help:

items.question: What do I do if I've lost my job?
items.answer: First, you need to register as a job seeker at nav.no. Then you can apply for unemployment benefits if you meet the requirements. You must have earned at least NOK 186,042 in the last year or NOK 372,084 in the last 3 years. See our guides for step-by-step help.

items.question: How long does it take to get a response to a NAV application?
items.answer: Processing time varies: Unemployment benefits usually take 3-4 weeks. Sick pay takes 2-4 weeks. Parental benefits take 4-6 weeks. You can check the status of your application under "My cases" at nav.no.

items.question: What happens if I forget to submit my employment status form?
items.answer: Then you won't receive payment for that period. You can submit the form up to 8 days late, but you'll have a deduction from your payment. After 8 days, you lose the money for that period. Set a reminder on your phone!

items.question: Can I travel abroad while receiving unemployment benefits?
items.answer: You can take vacation for up to 4 weeks per year, but you won't receive unemployment benefits for vacation days. You must apply to NAV for approval BEFORE you travel, and you must still submit the employment status form.

items.question: What's the difference between sick pay and AAP?
items.answer: Sick pay is for when you're temporarily ill (up to 1 year). AAP (work assessment allowance) is for those who are still sick after sick pay ends and need help returning to work or clarifying their work capacity.

items.question: When does the tax return arrive?
items.answer: The tax return usually becomes available in March. You'll receive a notification by SMS or email. The deadline to check and submit changes is April 30th.

items.question: What do I do if there's an error in my tax return?
items.answer: Log in to skatteetaten.no, open the tax return and click "Change" next to the item you want to correct. You can make changes as many times as you want before the deadline. After the deadline, you can submit an amendment.

items.question: When do I receive my tax settlement?
items.answer: Most people receive their tax settlement in June. Some have to wait until autumn. You'll be notified when it's ready. Refunds are automatically paid to your account.

items.question: What's the difference between tax card and tax return?
items.answer: The tax card determines how much tax is deducted from your salary THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. The tax return is the settlement for what has ALREADY BEEN PAID - it shows whether you paid too much or too little.

items.question: What deductions do people most often forget?
items.answer: The most commonly forgotten deductions are: Travel expenses to work (if over 37 km), interest expenses on loans, union dues, donations to charitable organizations, and parent deductions for kindergarten/after-school care.

items.question: How do I change my GP?
items.answer: Log in to helsenorge.no, go to "GP" and select "Change GP". You can search by name or location. You can change up to 2 times per year. The change takes effect from the first day of the next month.

items.question: What do I do if my GP has a full list?
items.answer: You can put yourself on a waiting list, choose another doctor, or contact your municipality. Everyone has the right to a GP, and the municipality must help you if there are no available spots.

items.question: Can the doctor refuse to renew my prescription?
items.answer: Yes, if the doctor believes a new assessment is necessary first. Some medications require regular follow-up. Then you must book an appointment to get the prescription renewed.

items.question: What is the exemption card limit and how does it work?
items.answer: The exemption card limit is approximately NOK 3,040 (2024). When you've paid this much in co-payments (doctor visits, medicine, etc.), you automatically receive an exemption card. Then you're exempt from co-payments for the rest of the year.

items.question: Can I read my medical records from the hospital?
items.answer: Yes, most hospitals send records to Helsenorge. Some documentation may be delayed or blocked by the doctor. You can request access directly from the hospital if you can't find it.

items.question: I don't have BankID - what do I do?
items.answer: Contact your bank to get BankID. You can also use MinID for some services. Without BankID/MinID, you can show up in person at a NAV office or use a power of attorney through relatives.

items.question: Why isn't my BankID working?
items.answer: Common reasons: The app needs to be updated, you've entered the wrong code 3 times (locked), or the bank has blocked your BankID. Try updating the app or contact your bank.

items.question: Can someone else log in for me?
items.answer: You should NEVER share your BankID code with others. If you need help, relatives can get power of attorney. Contact the relevant agency (NAV, Tax Office) to arrange power of attorney.

items.question: When can I withdraw retirement pension?
items.answer: You can withdraw retirement pension from age 62, but the earlier you start, the lower your monthly payment. If you wait until 67 or later, you'll receive more per month. You can check your pension at nav.no/pensjon.

items.question: Can I work while receiving pension?
items.answer: Yes! You can work as much as you want without the pension being reduced. Since 2011, the rules were changed so that work and pension can be combined freely. You still pay tax on employment income.

items.question: What is AFP (contractual early retirement pension)?
items.answer: AFP is a supplementary pension for those who work in the private sector with a collective agreement or in the public sector. You must apply for AFP before you turn 62. AFP provides a lifelong supplement to retirement pension.

items.question: Do I get pension if I've worked little?
items.answer: Everyone living in Norway receives a guaranteed pension (minimum pension) from age 67, even if you've worked little or nothing. The amount depends on how long you've lived in Norway (requires at least 5 years). Full guaranteed pension requires 40 years of residence.

items.question: How do I apply for retirement pension?
items.answer: Log in to nav.no/pensjon with BankID. Select "Apply for pension" and follow the steps. You should apply 3-4 months before you want to start withdrawing. NAV also helps by phone at 55 55 33 34.

items.question: What happens to my pension if my spouse dies?
items.answer: You may be entitled to survivor's pension if you were married or cohabiting with shared children. This benefit is means-tested. Contact NAV as soon as possible after the death to check your rights.

items.question: How do I know if an SMS from NAV/the bank is real?
items.answer: Real SMS from NAV/bank NEVER ask for passwords, BankID or account numbers. They don't contain links to log in. Unsure? Don't click the link - log in directly at nav.no or the bank's website instead.

items.question: Someone called and said they were from Microsoft - is it a scam?
items.answer: YES, this is almost always a scam! Microsoft NEVER calls unsolicited. If you gave access to your PC: Turn off the PC, contact the bank, and get help checking the PC for malware. Call the police at 02800.

items.question: I think I've been scammed - what do I do?
items.answer: Act FAST: 1) Contact your bank immediately to block card/account. 2) Change passwords on email and important services. 3) Report to police online or call 02800. 4) Contact ID theft help at 21 05 32 80.

items.question: My grandchild calls and urgently needs money - what do I do?
items.answer: STOP! This could be "grandparent scam". Scammers pretend to be family in distress. ALWAYS verify by calling back on the number you ALREADY have. Ask about something only you know. Real family understands you need to check.

items.question: Is it safe to shop online?
items.answer: Yes, if you follow some rules: Look for the padlock in the address bar. Use known stores. Pay by card or Vipps (not bank transfer). Does the price seem too good? Then it's often a scam. Check reviews on Trustpilot.

items.question: What is a secure password?
items.answer: A good password is LONG (at least 12 characters) and unique for each service. Use a sentence: "MyCatIsNamedFluffy3!" is better than "C@t123". Never write passwords in email or SMS. Consider a password book (on paper) or password manager.

items.question: How do I update my phone?
items.answer: iPhone: Settings → General → Software Update. Android: Settings → System → Software Update. Connect to Wi-Fi and charger before updating. Updates provide better security!

items.question: I've forgotten my password - what do I do?
items.answer: Most websites have a "Forgot password" link on the login page. Click there and follow the instructions - you'll usually receive an email with a link to create a new password. For BankID: Contact your bank.

items.question: What's the difference between Wi-Fi and mobile data?
items.answer: Wi-Fi is wireless internet from a router (at home, café, library) - often free and faster. Mobile data uses your phone subscription and costs money. Use Wi-Fi at home to save mobile data.

items.question: How do I take a screenshot on my phone?
items.answer: iPhone: Press side button + volume up at the same time. Android: Press power button + volume down at the same time. The image is saved in your photo gallery. Useful for showing error messages to someone who can help!

items.question: Where can I get help with computers and technology?
items.answer: Your library often has free computer help. Seniornett Norway (seniornett.no) has courses and phone support. The volunteer center can also help. Many municipalities also have digital help services for the elderly.

items.question: What is an app and how do I download apps?
items.answer: An app is a program on your phone (e.g., BankID, Vipps). To download: Open App Store (iPhone) or Google Play (Android), search for the app and tap "Get" or "Install". Some apps require you to create an account.

favorites.title: My Favorites
favorites.subtitle: Here you'll find the guides you've saved as favorites.
favorites.emptyText: Click the star on a guide to save it here for quick access.
favorites.tipText: Your favorites are saved on this device. If you use a different device or delete browser data, they will disappear.

about.title: About LettDigital
about.missionIntro: Many people in Norway, both Norwegians and newcomers, struggle with digital public services. They risk being excluded from important services like NAV, the Tax Office, and Health Norway.
about.missionText: LettDigital was created to make it easier for everyone to understand and use these services. We explain complicated processes with simple words, large fonts, and step-by-step guides.
about.whoAreWeText1: LettDigital is an independent project that wants to help those who fall outside the digital society. We are not affiliated with NAV, the Tax Office, or Health Norway, but we have great respect for the work these agencies do.
about.whoAreWeText2: Our information is based on official information from the relevant agencies, but we always recommend checking the official websites for the latest information.
about.accessibilityIntro: We have designed LettDigital with all users in mind:

accessibilityFeatures.fontSize: Adjustable text size - Make the text larger with the button in the bottom right
accessibilityFeatures.contrast: High contrast mode - For better readability
accessibilityFeatures.simpleLanguage: Simple language - We avoid difficult words and jargon
accessibilityFeatures.keyboard: Keyboard navigation - All functions can be used without a mouse
accessibilityFeatures.screenReader: Screen reader friendly - Compatible with assistive devices

about.contactText: Do you have questions, suggestions for improvements, or have you found an error? We greatly appreciate feedback!
about.importantInfoText: LettDigital provides general guidance and is not an official service. For binding information about your rights and obligations, always check the official websites: nav.no, skatteetaten.no, and helsenorge.no. When in doubt, contact the relevant agency directly.

stepGuide.allStepsComplete: You have completed all the steps in this guide.

search.placeholder: Search for guides... (e.g., unemployment, prescription, tax)
search.tryOther: Try other search terms or see our categories

whoAreWe.title: Who are we?
whoAreWe.text1: LettDigital is an information service that helps people use public digital services. We are not part of NAV, the Tax Office, or Health Norway, but provide guidance based on publicly available information.

dataCollection.title: What data do we collect?
dataCollection.intro: We collect minimal data and only what is necessary for the website to function:
dataCollection.localSettings: Local settings: Text size, contrast mode, and favorites are stored only in your browser (localStorage)
dataCollection.cookieConsent: Cookie consent: We remember if you have accepted or rejected cookies
dataCollection.serviceUsage: Information about your use of public services
dataCollection.thirdPartyData: Data shared with third parties for advertising

cookies.title: Cookies
cookies.intro: We only use necessary cookies that are stored locally in your browser:
cookies.noAnalytics: We do not use analytics cookies (like Google Analytics) or advertising cookies.

thirdParties.title: Sharing with third parties
thirdParties.noSharing: We share no data with third parties. All information remains in your browser.
thirdParties.hosting: The website is hosted by Vercel, which may log technical information (IP address, browser type) for security purposes.
thirdParties.vercelLink: See Vercel's privacy policy for more information.

yourRights.title: Your rights
yourRights.intro: Under GDPR and Norwegian privacy legislation, you have the right to:
yourRights.delete: Delete data: Clear your browser's local storage to remove all settings
yourRights.access: Access data: All data is stored locally in your browser and visible to you
yourRights.withdraw: Withdraw consent: You can delete cookies in your browser settings at any time

security.title: Security
security.text: The website uses HTTPS encryption for secure communication. Since we do not collect personal data, there is minimal risk of data leakage.

contactUs.title: Contact us
contactUs.text: Do you have questions about privacy? Contact us at:

updates.title: Changes to the privacy policy
updates.text: We may update this statement as needed. Significant changes will be announced on the website.
